greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Maximal digit value used when n is written in primorial base (cf. A049345).
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..30030
Index entries for sequences related to primorial base
example: For n = 2105, which could be expressed in primorial base for example as "T0021" (where T here stands for the digit value ten), or maybe more elegantly as [10,0,0,2,1] as 2105 = 10*A002110(4) + 2*A002110(1) + 1*A002110(0). The maximum value of these digits is 10, thus a(2105) = 10.
mathematica: With[{b = MixedRadix[Reverse@ Prime@ Range@ 20]}, Array[Max@ IntegerDigits[#, b] &, 105, 0]] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Oct 30 2019 *)
program: (PARI) A328114(n) = { my(i=0,m=0,pr=1,nextpr); while((n>0),i=i+1; nextpr = prime(i)*pr; if((n%nextpr),m = max(m,(n%nextpr)/pr); n-=(n%nextpr));pr=nextpr); (m); };
(PARI) A328114(n) = { my(s=0, p=2); while(n, s = max(s,(n%p)); n = n\p; p = nextprime(1+p)); (s); }; \\ (Faster, no unnecessary construction of primorials) - _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 29 2019
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 12 2019
